unnormalised: The buzz around AI is getting louder, especially after the recent "AI for India" summit held in Delhi on 10/11/2024. Tech enthusiasts and policymakers alike were discussing everything from AI-powered agricultural solutions to the ethical implications of deepfakes. The summit saw participation from leading figures like Dr. Rajesh Kumar from IIT Kanpur, who showcased a groundbreaking AI model for predicting crop yields.
normalised: The buzz around A-I is getting louder, especially after the recent "A-I for India" summit held in Delhi on tenth november two thousand and twenty four. Tech enthusiasts and policymakers alike were discussing everything from A-I powered agricultural solutions to the ethical implications of deepfakes. The summit saw participation from leading figures like Doctor Rajesh Kumar from I-I-T Kanpur, who showcased a groundbreaking A-I model for predicting crop yields.

unnormalised: However, some concerns were raised by cybersecurity experts regarding the potential misuse of AI. A report presented at the conference highlighted that 67% of Indian businesses are vulnerable to AI-powered cyberattacks. Companies like TCS and Infosys are now heavily investing in AI-driven security solutions to combat these threats. The government is also planning to introduce stricter regulations by 01/01/2025 to ensure responsible AI development and deployment.

unnormalised: Looking ahead, it's clear that AI will continue to reshape various sectors in India.
